11224Structural ChemistryComputational and Experimental Studies of Chemical and Biological SystemsStruct Chem1040-04001572-9001Springer USBostons11224-008-9285-z928510.1007/s11224-008-9285-zOriginal ResearchA novel layered supramolecular compound containing 2D network of eight-member water clusters and terephthalato extended-bridgedYangPeng1ChenXi1RenShi1MaShu-Lin1dgrid.464478.d0000000097290286Department of Application Chemistry, College of ScienceTianjin University of Commerce300134TianjinPeople’s Republic of China+86-22-26686507+86-22-26686507mashulin@tjcu.edu.cn15220084200819229129516120082610200716120081522008© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 20082008Abstract

A novel layered supramolecular compound [Ni(L)(TPHA)]·8H2O, containing two-dimensional (2D) water clusters and terephthalato-bridged ligand, where L = 1,3,6,9,11,14-hexaazatricyclo[12.2.1.16,9] octadecane, TPHA = terephthalate dianion, has been synthesized and structurally characterized by spectroscopy and X-ray crystallography. The complex is neutral, in which the nickel(II) ions are bridged by the TPHA to form a one-dimensional (1D) infinite chain structure, and containing the eight-member water cluster. The presence of octameric water clusters have effectively increased the 1D coordination polymer to a three-dimensional layered structure. Every water cluster is connected strongly by a O–H···O hydrogen bond (range of the bonds between 2.724 and 3.056 Å). The complex crystallizes in monoclinic, space group P21/c with a = 9.788(3), b = 13.030(4), c = 11.646(4) Å, and β = 104.551(5)°.

KeywordsLayered complexWater clusterHydrogen bondCrystal structurevolume-issue-count6issue-article-count31issue-toc-levels0issue-copyright-holderSpringer Science+Business Media, LLCissue-copyright-year2008article-contains-esmNoarticle-numbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-registration-date-year2008article-registration-date-month1article-registration-date-day16article-toc-levels0toc-levels0volume-typeRegularjournal-productArchiveJournalnumbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-grants-typeRegularmetadata-grantOpenAccessabstract-grantOpenAccessbodypdf-grantRestrictedbodyhtml-grantRestrictedbibliography-grantRestrictedesm-grantOpenAccessonline-firstfalsepdf-file-referenceBodyRef/PDF/11224_2008_Article_9285.pdftarget-typeOnlinePDFissue-online-date-year2008issue-online-date-month7issue-online-date-day1issue-print-date-year2008issue-print-date-month7issue-print-date-day1issue-typeRegulararticle-typeOriginalPaperjournal-subject-primaryChemistryjournal-subject-secondaryTheoretical and Computational Chemistry journal-subject-secondaryPhysical Chemistry journal-subject-secondaryComputer Applications in Chemistry open-accessfalseIntroduction

The design and synthesis of self-assembling supramolecular systems are an area of intense interest as a route to the rational generation of functional materials [1, 2]. A rapidly developing area in this field is the synthesis of extended inorganic structures, where the ability to control functionality along these networks is of much current interest [3, 4]. Recently, weak intermolecular interactions, such as hydrogen bonding [5–10], as well as π···π and C–H···π interactions [11–14] are often used to construct networks from one-dimensional (1D) chains or two-dimensional (2D) sheets. But three-dimensional (3D) polymetallic supramolecular structures constructed from 1D chains through the presence of water clusters are seldom reported [15, 16]. Recent studies of the stereochemistry of 1D, 2D, and 3D assemblies of transition metal complexes have revealed an interesting set of water clusters stabilized within the crystals by hydrogen bonds. Here, we report the structure of a novel self-assembled 3D layered supramolecular compound containing 8-member cycle water clusters with an ice-like chair conformation. In the structure of the complex, 1D chains are formed by Ni(L)2+ and TPHA, and they are packed like a plywood and linked together by the hydrogen-bonding interactions to give rise to a 3D network. Altogether, water clusters are strongly hydrogen bonded to H–N and H–C of Ni(L)2+ and oxygen of the TPHA. We describe herein the structure of the complex.

ExperimentalMaterials and methods

All reagents used in the syntheses were of analytical grade and were used without further purification. Distilled water was used for all procedures. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were carried out on a Perkin–Elmer elemental analyzer (model 240). The infrared spectrum was obtained on a Perkin–Elmer 983G infrared spectroscopy in the 4000–400 cm−1 regions, using KBr pellets.

The precursor complex [Ni(L)](ClO4)2 was prepared according to the literature procedures previously reported [17].

Preparation of complex

Preparation of [Ni(L)(TPHA)]·8H2O: 5 mL of an aqueous solution of piperidinium terephthalate salt (100.8 mg, 0.3 mmol) was added dropwise to a solution of [Ni(L)](ClO4)2 (153.6 mg, 0.3 mmol) in water (10 mL). The mixture was stirred at 60 °C for 0.5 h. The resulting solution was filtered and kept at room temperature for a few hours to give pink needle crystals suitable for the X-ray structural analysis. Yield: 88 mg (34.6%). Anal. Calcd. for C20H46N6O12Ni: C, 38.66; H, 7.46; N,13.53%. Found: C, 38.69; H, 7.24; N, 13.65%.

X-ray crystallography

All measurements were made on a Bruker Smart 1000 detector with graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation. The empirical absorption corrections by Semi-empirical from equivalents were carried out. The structure was solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 program and refined with SHELXL-97 [18] by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F2. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, while the hydrogen atoms were located geometrically and refined isotropically. Complete crystallographic data and collection parameters are listed in Table 1.

Results and discussionGeneral characterizations

The significant bands in the IR spectra of the complex exhibit two characteristic strong bands at 1600 and 1380 cm−1, respectively, which can be attributed to the νas(COO−) and νs(COO−) stretching vibrations of the carboxylato group. In addition, the separation between νas and νs has often been used to diagnose the coordination models of the carboxylato group. The separate value between νas and νs for the complex is greater than 200 cm−1 (Δν = 220 cm−1), suggesting a monodentate coordination mode for the complex. This is consistent with the X-ray structure analysis. On the other hand, the O–H stretching frequency of the water clusters as a broad band was found at around 3300 cm−1.

Description of the structure

As shown in Fig. 1, the structure of the complex consists of 1D infinite chain coordination polymers with a basic Ni(L)(TPHA) unit. Selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table 2. The coordination environment around the central Ni(II) ion shows an axially elongated octahedron with four Ni–N bonds with bond lengths Ni(1)–N(1) = Ni(1)–N(1)#1 = 2.0333(17) Å (symmetry code: #1 −x + 2, −y, −z + 2), Ni(1)–N(2) = Ni(1)–N(2)#1 = 2.1072(18) Å, respectively. The Ni–O bond distance is 2.1634(14) Å (Ni(1)–O(1)#1 = Ni(1)–O(1) = 2.1634(14) Å), which is considerably longer than the Ni–N bond distance of average 2.0703 Å. In the complex, the symmetric unit of the structure contain a bridged-TPHA and a Ni(L)2+ fragments, and each COO− of μ-TPHA as a monodentate ligand coordinated with Ni atom, in which Ni atom and TPHA is almost in the same plane, and the torsion angles of Ni(1)–O(1)–C(7)–O(2) = 1.6(3)°, Ni(1)–O(1)–C(7)–C(8) = −179.00(11)°. For the complex, one structurally interesting feature is found, that is, water clusters structure has been presented, and each water cluster consists of eight water molecules, through H-bond interaction to form the eight-member rings structure with an ice-like chair conformation (see Fig. 2a), and the structure further has been extended through four hydrogen bonds from four different water clusters to form a sheet-like, 2D network of water clusters, as shown in Fig. 2b. Selected H-bond distances are listed in Table 3. As shown in Fig. 3a, two of the eight water molecules of each water cluster are coordinated with the oxygen atom of the TPHA, with bond distances are 2.838 Å [Ow(3)–O(2)] and 2.788 Å [Ow(5)–O(2)] (symmetry code: −x + 1, −y, −z + 1), respectively, and the other two water molecules are, respectively, connected the nitrogen and hydrogen atom of Ni(L)2+ through hydrogen bond. The 1D chains are bound on the two sides of the water clusters one by one in order. Every two neighboring chains are mutual parallelism, each chain is interconnected by a network of water clusters through hydrogen-bonding interactions. The hydrogen bonds are involved resulting in the formation of an ultimate constructing 3D supramolecular network (see Fig. 3b). Also we find that the intramolecular Ni-Ni′ distance is 11.646(3) Å, whereas the intermolecular Ni–Ni′ one is 9.787(4) Å.

In addition, the terephthalato dianion has been proved to be an appropriate bridging unit to design very interesting magnetic systems with a separation of 11–12 Å between the magnetic centers [19, 21]. Because Ni2+ ion (S = 1) and TPHA are connected alternatively, we can predict that the complex would have a good electronics delivery and represent magnetic superexchange interaction. But we are anxious about that the longer distance of the electronics delivers may weaken the magnetic property. The further of magnetic property research work is still carrying on.

Conclusions

It should be noted that structurally characterized the self-assembled, containing 2D network of water clusters layered supramolecular complexes are still rare. In the paper, a novel supramolecular complex [Ni(L)(TPHA)]·8H2O was synthesized from the mononuclear fragment [Ni(L)](ClO4)2 and the TPHA dianion, and crystallized, and structurally characterized for the first time. The complex is a 3D layered polymetallic supramolecular compound containing multilayers 1D chains and 2D water clusters. One thing well worth mentioning is that we have also characterized a novel the eight-member cycle of water cluster with a chair conformation which gives rise to a sheet-like network of water clusters through interaction of the water cluster.

Supplementary material

Crystallographic data for the structural analysis has been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, CCDC No. 652175 for the complex. Copy of this information can be obtained free of charge from The Director, CCDC, 12 Union road, Cambridge, CB2 1EZ, UK (fax: +44-1223-336033; email: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk or http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

Acknowledgment

This project was supported by the SRT Foundation of Tianjin University of Commerce, P.R. China (No. 2007120).

elements.content: A novel layered supramolecular compound [Ni(L)(TPHA)]·8H2O, containing two-dimensional (2D) water clusters and terephthalato-bridged ligand, where L = 1,3,6,9,11,14-hexaazatricyclo[12.2.1.16,9] octadecane, TPHA = terephthalate dianion, has been synthesized and structurally characterized by spectroscopy and X-ray crystallography. The complex is neutral, in which the nickel(II) ions are bridged by the TPHA to form a one-dimensional (1D) infinite chain structure, and containing the eight-member water cluster. The presence of octameric water clusters have effectively increased the 1D coordination polymer to a three-dimensional layered structure. Every water cluster is connected strongly by a O–H···O hydrogen bond (range of the bonds between 2.724 and 3.056 Å). The complex crystallizes in monoclinic, space group P21/c with a = 9.788(3), b = 13.030(4), c = 11.646(4) Å, and β = 104.551(5)°.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A novel layered supramolecular compound [Ni(L)(TPHA)]⋅8H2O, containing two-dimensional (2D) water clusters and terephthalato-bridged ligand, where L = 1,3,6,9,11,14-hexaazatricyclo[12.2.1.16,9] octadecane, TPHA = terephthalate dianion, has been synthesized and structurally characterized by spectroscopy and X-ray crystallography. The complex is neutral, in which the nickel(II) ions are bridged by the TPHA to form a one-dimensional (1D) infinite chain structure, and containing the eight-member water cluster. The presence of octameric water clusters have effectively increased the 1D coordination polymer to a three-dimensional layered structure. Every water cluster is connected strongly by a O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bond (range of the bonds between 2.724 and 3.056 Å). The complex crystallizes in monoclinic, space group P21/c with a = 9.788(3), b = 13.030(4), c = 11.646(4) Å, and β = 104.551(5)°.

elements.content: The design and synthesis of self-assembling supramolecular systems are an area of intense interest as a route to the rational generation of functional materials [1, 2]. A rapidly developing area in this field is the synthesis of extended inorganic structures, where the ability to control functionality along these networks is of much current interest [3, 4]. Recently, weak intermolecular interactions, such as hydrogen bonding [5–10], as well as π···π and C–H···π interactions [11–14] are often used to construct networks from one-dimensional (1D) chains or two-dimensional (2D) sheets. But three-dimensional (3D) polymetallic supramolecular structures constructed from 1D chains through the presence of water clusters are seldom reported [15, 16]. Recent studies of the stereochemistry of 1D, 2D, and 3D assemblies of transition metal complexes have revealed an interesting set of water clusters stabilized within the crystals by hydrogen bonds. Here, we report the structure of a novel self-assembled 3D layered supramolecular compound containing 8-member cycle water clusters with an ice-like chair conformation. In the structure of the complex, 1D chains are formed by Ni(L)2+ and TPHA, and they are packed like a plywood and linked together by the hydrogen-bonding interactions to give rise to a 3D network. Altogether, water clusters are strongly hydrogen bonded to H–N and H–C of Ni(L)2+ and oxygen of the TPHA. We describe herein the structure of the complex.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and synthesis of self-assembling supramolecular systems are an area of intense interest as a route to the rational generation of functional materials [1, 2]. A rapidly developing area in this field is the synthesis of extended inorganic structures, where the ability to control functionality along these networks is of much current interest [3, 4]. Recently, weak intermolecular interactions, such as hydrogen bonding [5-10], as well as π⋅⋅⋅π and C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions [11-14] are often used to construct networks from one-dimensional (1D) chains or two-dimensional (2D) sheets. But three-dimensional (3D) polymetallic supramolecular structures constructed from 1D chains through the presence of water clusters are seldom reported [15, 16]. Recent studies of the stereochemistry of 1D, 2D, and 3D assemblies of transition metal complexes have revealed an interesting set of water clusters stabilized within the crystals by hydrogen bonds. Here, we report the structure of a novel self-assembled 3D layered supramolecular compound containing 8-member cycle water clusters with an ice-like chair conformation. In the structure of the complex, 1D chains are formed by Ni(L)2+ and TPHA, and they are packed like a plywood and linked together by the hydrogen-bonding interactions to give rise to a 3D network. Altogether, water clusters are strongly hydrogen bonded to H-N and H-C of Ni(L)2+ and oxygen of the TPHA. We describe herein the structure of the complex.

elements.content: All reagents used in the syntheses were of analytical grade and were used without further purification. Distilled water was used for all procedures. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were carried out on a Perkin–Elmer elemental analyzer (model 240). The infrared spectrum was obtained on a Perkin–Elmer 983G infrared spectroscopy in the 4000–400 cm−1 regions, using KBr pellets.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and methods

All reagents used in the syntheses were of analytical grade and were used without further purification. Distilled water was used for all procedures. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer elemental analyzer (model 240). The infrared spectrum was obtained on a Perkin-Elmer 983G infrared spectroscopy in the 4000-400 cm-1 regions, using KBr pellets.

elements.content:
The precursor complex [Ni(L)](ClO4)2 was prepared according to the literature procedures previously reported [17].

Preparation of complex

Preparation of [Ni(L)(TPHA)]·8H2O: 5 mL of an aqueous solution of piperidinium terephthalate salt (100.8 mg, 0.3 mmol) was added dropwise to a solution of [Ni(L)](ClO4)2 (153.6 mg, 0.3 mmol) in water (10 mL). The mixture was stirred at 60 °C for 0.5 h. The resulting solution was filtered and kept at room temperature for a few hours to give pink needle crystals suitable for the X-ray structural analysis. Yield: 88 mg (34.6%). Anal. Calcd. for C20H46N6O12Ni: C, 38.66; H, 7.46; N,13.53%. Found: C, 38.69; H, 7.24; N, 13.65%.
elements.clean_text:
The precursor complex [Ni(L)](ClO4)2 was prepared according to the literature procedures previously reported [17].

Preparation of complex

Preparation of [Ni(L)(TPHA)]⋅8H2O: 5 mL of an aqueous solution of piperidinium terephthalate salt (100.8 mg, 0.3 mmol) was added dropwise to a solution of [Ni(L)](ClO4)2 (153.6 mg, 0.3 mmol) in water (10 mL). The mixture was stirred at 60 °C for 0.5 h. The resulting solution was filtered and kept at room temperature for a few hours to give pink needle crystals suitable for the X-ray structural analysis. Yield: 88 mg (34.6%). Anal. Calcd. for C20H46N6O12Ni: C, 38.66; H, 7.46; N,13.53%. Found: C, 38.69; H, 7.24; N, 13.65%.

elements.content: All measurements were made on a Bruker Smart 1000 detector with graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation. The empirical absorption corrections by Semi-empirical from equivalents were carried out. The structure was solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 program and refined with SHELXL-97 [18] by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F2. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, while the hydrogen atoms were located geometrically and refined isotropically. Complete crystallographic data and collection parameters are listed in Table 1.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

All measurements were made on a Bruker Smart 1000 detector with graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation. The empirical absorption corrections by Semi-empirical from equivalents were carried out. The structure was solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 program and refined with SHELXL-97 [18] by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F2. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, while the hydrogen atoms were located geometrically and refined isotropically. Complete crystallographic data and collection parameters are listed in Table 1.

The significant bands in the IR spectra of the complex exhibit two characteristic strong bands at 1600 and 1380 cm−1, respectively, which can be attributed to the νas(COO−) and νs(COO−) stretching vibrations of the carboxylato group. In addition, the separation between νas and νs has often been used to diagnose the coordination models of the carboxylato group. The separate value between νas and νs for the complex is greater than 200 cm−1 (Δν = 220 cm−1), suggesting a monodentate coordination mode for the complex. This is consistent with the X-ray structure analysis. On the other hand, the O–H stretching frequency of the water clusters as a broad band was found at around 3300 cm−1.
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

General characterizations

The significant bands in the IR spectra of the complex exhibit two characteristic strong bands at 1600 and 1380 cm-1, respectively, which can be attributed to the νas(COO-) and νs(COO-) stretching vibrations of the carboxylato group. In addition, the separation between νas and νs has often been used to diagnose the coordination models of the carboxylato group. The separate value between νas and νs for the complex is greater than 200 cm-1 (Δν = 220 cm-1), suggesting a monodentate coordination mode for the complex. This is consistent with the X-ray structure analysis. On the other hand, the O-H stretching frequency of the water clusters as a broad band was found at around 3300 cm-1.

elements.content: As shown in Fig. 1, the structure of the complex consists of 1D infinite chain coordination polymers with a basic Ni(L)(TPHA) unit. Selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table 2. The coordination environment around the central Ni(II) ion shows an axially elongated octahedron with four Ni–N bonds with bond lengths Ni(1)–N(1) = Ni(1)–N(1)#1 = 2.0333(17) Å (symmetry code: #1 −x + 2, −y, −z + 2), Ni(1)–N(2) = Ni(1)–N(2)#1 = 2.1072(18) Å, respectively. The Ni–O bond distance is 2.1634(14) Å (Ni(1)–O(1)#1 = Ni(1)–O(1) = 2.1634(14) Å), which is considerably longer than the Ni–N bond distance of average 2.0703 Å. In the complex, the symmetric unit of the structure contain a bridged-TPHA and a Ni(L)2+ fragments, and each COO− of μ-TPHA as a monodentate ligand coordinated with Ni atom, in which Ni atom and TPHA is almost in the same plane, and the torsion angles of Ni(1)–O(1)–C(7)–O(2) = 1.6(3)°, Ni(1)–O(1)–C(7)–C(8) = −179.00(11)°. For the complex, one structurally interesting feature is found, that is, water clusters structure has been presented, and each water cluster consists of eight water molecules, through H-bond interaction to form the eight-member rings structure with an ice-like chair conformation (see Fig. 2a), and the structure further has been extended through four hydrogen bonds from four different water clusters to form a sheet-like, 2D network of water clusters, as shown in Fig. 2b. Selected H-bond distances are listed in Table 3. As shown in Fig. 3a, two of the eight water molecules of each water cluster are coordinated with the oxygen atom of the TPHA, with bond distances are 2.838 Å [Ow(3)–O(2)] and 2.788 Å [Ow(5)–O(2)] (symmetry code: −x + 1, −y, −z + 1), respectively, and the other two water molecules are, respectively, connected the nitrogen and hydrogen atom of Ni(L)2+ through hydrogen bond. The 1D chains are bound on the two sides of the water clusters one by one in order. Every two neighboring chains are mutual parallelism, each chain is interconnected by a network of water clusters through hydrogen-bonding interactions. The hydrogen bonds are involved resulting in the formation of an ultimate constructing 3D supramolecular network (see Fig. 3b). Also we find that the intramolecular Ni-Ni′ distance is 11.646(3) Å, whereas the intermolecular Ni–Ni′ one is 9.787(4) Å.
elements.clean_text:
Description of the structure

As shown in Fig. 1, the structure of the complex consists of 1D infinite chain coordination polymers with a basic Ni(L)(TPHA) unit. Selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table 2. The coordination environment around the central Ni(II) ion shows an axially elongated octahedron with four Ni-N bonds with bond lengths Ni(1)-N(1) = Ni(1)-N(1)#1 = 2.0333(17) Å (symmetry code: #1 -x + 2, -y, -z + 2), Ni(1)-N(2) = Ni(1)-N(2)#1 = 2.1072(18) Å, respectively. The Ni-O bond distance is 2.1634(14) Å (Ni(1)-O(1)#1 = Ni(1)-O(1) = 2.1634(14) Å), which is considerably longer than the Ni-N bond distance of average 2.0703 Å. In the complex, the symmetric unit of the structure contain a bridged-TPHA and a Ni(L)2+ fragments, and each COO- of μ-TPHA as a monodentate ligand coordinated with Ni atom, in which Ni atom and TPHA is almost in the same plane, and the torsion angles of Ni(1)-O(1)-C(7)-O(2) = 1.6(3)°, Ni(1)-O(1)-C(7)-C(8) = -179.00(11)°. For the complex, one structurally interesting feature is found, that is, water clusters structure has been presented, and each water cluster consists of eight water molecules, through H-bond interaction to form the eight-member rings structure with an ice-like chair conformation (see Fig. 2a), and the structure further has been extended through four hydrogen bonds from four different water clusters to form a sheet-like, 2D network of water clusters, as shown in Fig. 2b. Selected H-bond distances are listed in Table 3. As shown in Fig. 3a, two of the eight water molecules of each water cluster are coordinated with the oxygen atom of the TPHA, with bond distances are 2.838 Å [Ow(3)-O(2)] and 2.788 Å [Ow(5)-O(2)] (symmetry code: -x + 1, -y, -z + 1), respectively, and the other two water molecules are, respectively, connected the nitrogen and hydrogen atom of Ni(L)2+ through hydrogen bond. The 1D chains are bound on the two sides of the water clusters one by one in order. Every two neighboring chains are mutual parallelism, each chain is interconnected by a network of water clusters through hydrogen-bonding interactions. The hydrogen bonds are involved resulting in the formation of an ultimate constructing 3D supramolecular network (see Fig. 3b). Also we find that the intramolecular Ni-Ni' distance is 11.646(3) Å, whereas the intermolecular Ni-Ni' one is 9.787(4) Å.

elements.content: In addition, the terephthalato dianion has been proved to be an appropriate bridging unit to design very interesting magnetic systems with a separation of 11–12 Å between the magnetic centers [19, 21]. Because Ni2+ ion (S = 1) and TPHA are connected alternatively, we can predict that the complex would have a good electronics delivery and represent magnetic superexchange interaction. But we are anxious about that the longer distance of the electronics delivers may weaken the magnetic property. The further of magnetic property research work is still carrying on.
elements.clean_text: In addition, the terephthalato dianion has been proved to be an appropriate bridging unit to design very interesting magnetic systems with a separation of 11-12 Å between the magnetic centers [19, 21]. Because Ni2+ ion (S = 1) and TPHA are connected alternatively, we can predict that the complex would have a good electronics delivery and represent magnetic superexchange interaction. But we are anxious about that the longer distance of the electronics delivers may weaken the magnetic property. The further of magnetic property research work is still carrying on.

elements.content: It should be noted that structurally characterized the self-assembled, containing 2D network of water clusters layered supramolecular complexes are still rare. In the paper, a novel supramolecular complex [Ni(L)(TPHA)]·8H2O was synthesized from the mononuclear fragment [Ni(L)](ClO4)2 and the TPHA dianion, and crystallized, and structurally characterized for the first time. The complex is a 3D layered polymetallic supramolecular compound containing multilayers 1D chains and 2D water clusters. One thing well worth mentioning is that we have also characterized a novel the eight-member cycle of water cluster with a chair conformation which gives rise to a sheet-like network of water clusters through interaction of the water cluster.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

It should be noted that structurally characterized the self-assembled, containing 2D network of water clusters layered supramolecular complexes are still rare. In the paper, a novel supramolecular complex [Ni(L)(TPHA)]⋅8H2O was synthesized from the mononuclear fragment [Ni(L)](ClO4)2 and the TPHA dianion, and crystallized, and structurally characterized for the first time. The complex is a 3D layered polymetallic supramolecular compound containing multilayers 1D chains and 2D water clusters. One thing well worth mentioning is that we have also characterized a novel the eight-member cycle of water cluster with a chair conformation which gives rise to a sheet-like network of water clusters through interaction of the water cluster.

The precursor complex [Ni(L)](ClO4)2 was prepared according to the literature procedures previously reported [17].

Preparation of complex

Preparation of [Ni(L)(TPHA)]·8H2O: 5 mL of an aqueous solution of piperidinium terephthalate salt (100.8 mg, 0.3 mmol) was added dropwise to a solution of [Ni(L)](ClO4)2 (153.6 mg, 0.3 mmol) in water (10 mL). The mixture was stirred at 60 °C for 0.5 h. The resulting solution was filtered and kept at room temperature for a few hours to give pink needle crystals suitable for the X-ray structural analysis. Yield: 88 mg (34.6%). Anal. Calcd. for C20H46N6O12Ni: C, 38.66; H, 7.46; N,13.53%. Found: C, 38.69; H, 7.24; N, 13.65%.

The mixture was stirred at 60 °C for 0.5 h. The resulting solution was filtered and kept at room temperature for a few hours to give pink needle crystals suitable for the X-ray structural analysis. cln_elements.content: The 1D chain structure of [Ni(L)(TPHA)]·8H2O

(a) Ball and stick representation of the octameric water cluster. Dotted lines show the H-bonding between the water molecules. Bond distances for the hydrogen bonding present are shown here. (b) Packing diagram of the sheet-like, 2D layer, of the water clusters
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 2(a) Ball and stick representation of the octameric water cluster. Dotted lines show the H-bonding between the water molecules. Bond distances for the hydrogen bonding present are shown here. (b) Packing diagram of the sheet-like, 2D layer, of the water clusters

cln_elements.content: (a) A 1D chain interacted with water clusters. (b) The 1D chains (nine mutual parallelism) are bound on the two sides of the water clusters one by one in order, resulting in the formation of a 3D polymetallic supramolecule network. Hydrogen atoms of non-water have omitted for clarity
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 3(a) A 1D chain interacted with water clusters. (b) The 1D chains (nine mutual parallelism) are bound on the two sides of the water clusters one by one in order, resulting in the formation of a 3D polymetallic supramolecule network. Hydrogen atoms of non-water have omitted for clarity

metadata.title: A novel layered supramolecular compound containing 2D network of eight-member water clusters and terephthalato extended-bridged
